summary: This is a 2021 opinion and order by Judge Alison J. Nathan denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to suppress evidence obtained via a grand jury subpoena to the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP (BSF). Maxwell argued the subpoena violated her Fifth and Fourth Amendment rights and due process because the documents were under a protective order from prior civil litigation. The court rejects all arguments, finding no constitutional violation and no basis for suppression or an evidentiary hearing. This is a court opinion and order (Document 307) filed by Judge Alison J. Nathan on June 25, 2021, in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The order denies Maxwell's motions to suppress evidence obtained via a grand jury subpoena that modified a protective order from prior civil litigation. The court analyzes claims of prosecutorial misconduct, due process violations, and the applicability of the Franks standard, concluding Maxwell failed to make the required showing for suppression or an evidentiary hearing.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case who is moving to suppress evidence obtained from her prior civil litigation, specifically her deposition transcripts. She is charged with making false statements in those depositions.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge authoring this opinion and order, which denies Maxwell's motions to suppress evidence.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the individual, along with Maxwell, whom the plaintiff in the 2015 civil case accused of sexually abusing her. Described as the target of the government's investigation.

persons.name: McMahon
persons.context: Then-Chief Judge who heard the government's ex parte application to modify the protective order in the civil case after the original judge passed away. She granted the application.

persons.name: Netburn
persons.context: Magistrate Judge who denied a similar government application in another case, applying the same legal standard but reaching a different conclusion.

persons.name: Judge McMahon
persons.context: The judge who presided over the April 9, 2019 proceeding and granted the government's application to modify a protective order to allow a grand jury subpoena. Her ruling is analyzed and upheld.

persons.name: Judge Netburn
persons.context: Mentioned as having reached the opposite conclusion from Judge McMahon on the modification of the protective order, though her decision is not detailed here.

connections.description: Maxwell is identified in the document as Epstein's 'head recruiter' of underage girls, and both were accused of sexual abuse by the civil plaintiff.
BSF represented the plaintiff suing Maxwell for defamation in the 2015 civil case. Maxwell's motion concerns documents BSF produced to the government from that case.
Judge McMahon presided over the proceeding where the government sought to modify a protective order related to Maxwell's prior civil case, which Maxwell later challenged.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judge in Maxwell's criminal case, ruling on her suppression motions in this order.

events.title: Civil Defamation Lawsuit Filed
events.description: An unnamed plaintiff sued Ghislaine Maxwell for defamation, alleging Maxwell accused her of lying about being sexually abused by Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Meeting Between BSF Attorneys and AUSA
events.description: Three attorneys from Boies Schiller Flexner LLP met with an Assistant U.S. Attorney to provide information on possible criminal conduct, focusing on Epstein and identifying Maxwell as his 'head recruiter'.

events.title: SDNY Formal Investigation Opened
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York formally opened its investigation into Jeffrey Epstein following Miami Herald articles about his conduct and plea deal.

events.title: First Ex Parte Hearing on Protective Order
events.description: Judge McMahon held a hearing on the government's ex parte application to modify the civil protective order to allow BSF to comply with a grand jury subpoena.

events.title: Second Ex Parte Hearing and Order
events.description: Judge McMahon held a second hearing and subsequently issued a sealed order and opinion granting the government's application to modify the protective order, allowing BSF to turn over documents.

events.title: Hearing on Modification of Protective Order
events.description: A proceeding before Judge McMahon where the government applied to modify a protective order from Maxwell's prior civil litigation to allow a grand jury subpoena for documents. The prosecutor made statements about communications with the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner (BSF).

events.title: Prior Communications with BSF
events.description: Mentioned as a time when there were earlier communications between the U.S. Attorney's Office and the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner (BSF), which were not disclosed to Judge McMahon during the 2019 hearing. These did not lead to a criminal investigation at that time.

events.title: Miami Herald Exposé and Investigation Start
events.description: The government represents that its present investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell began following the publication of a Miami Herald exposé in 2018.

events.title: Court Denies Suppression Motions
events.description: Judge Alison J. Nathan issues this order denying Ghislaine Maxwell's motions to suppress evidence obtained via the grand jury subpoena and for an evidentiary hearing.

keyFacts: The court denied Ghislaine Maxwell's motion to suppress her deposition transcripts and other documents obtained by the government via a grand jury subpoena to her former civil adversary's law firm, Boies Schiller Flexner LLP.

The court ruled Maxwell had no reasonable expectation of privacy in documents produced in civil litigation, even under a protective order, and thus the government's subpoena did not violate her Fourth Amendment rights.

The court held that a civil protective order does not guarantee testimony will be shielded from a subsequent criminal prosecution, and Maxwell could have invoked her Fifth Amendment right during the civil depositions but did not.

The document reveals that attorneys for Maxwell's civil accuser approached the U.S. Attorney's Office in early 2016, identifying Maxwell as Epstein's 'head recruiter' of underage girls, though no investigation was pursued at that time.
Maxwell is charged in the superseding indictment with making false statements under oath in the two depositions she gave in the 2015 civil case.
The court denies Ghislaine Maxwell's motions to suppress evidence obtained by the government through a grand jury subpoena that modified a protective order from her prior civil litigation.

The court applies the standard from Franks v. Delaware, requiring a showing of deliberate or reckless misrepresentation by the government and materiality to the judge's decision, and finds Maxwell failed to make a 'substantial preliminary showing' on either prong.

The opinion details an April 9, 2019 hearing before Judge McMahon where a prosecutor disclosed communications with law firm Boies Schiller Flexner (BSF) after the investigation began but not about a 2016 meeting; the court finds this omission was not a deliberate/reckless misrepresentation and was not necessary to Judge McMahon's ruling.

Judge McMahon's decision to modify the protective order was based on two independent grounds: that Maxwell could not have reasonably relied on the order to keep evidence from prosecutors, and that the government showed 'extraordinary circumstances' justifying ex parte modification.

The court rejects Maxwell's arguments that the government's actions violated due process or justified suppression under the court's inherent supervisory authority, finding no 'fundamentally unfair' or 'outrageous' misconduct.
